metadata.case_name: Insurers (Appellants) v. Owners and Injured Persons (Respondents)

facts.text: Suits filed against owners of motor cars for recovery of damages suffered by plaintiffs as a result of negligent driving of the cars.
Owners of the cars were insured against third party risks.
Insurers added as defendants to the suits under sub-s. (2) of s. 96 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939.
Insurers filed written statements taking defences other than those mentioned in sub-s. (2) of s. 96.
Plaintiffs contended that the written statements should be taken off the records as insurers could defend only on grounds in sub-s. (2).
In one suit, trial court held insurer could take only defences in sub-s. (2); in the other, insurers not confined to those defences.
Appeals to Punjab High Court from trial court decisions.
Punjab High Court held insurers could defend only on grounds in sub-s. (2) and no others.
Policies effected in terms of the Act and certificates of insurance under s. 96 duly issued.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defences available to an insurer added as a party under s. 96(2) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 are only those mentioned therein or all defences available at law.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-s. (2) of s. 96 states grounds based on policy of insurance on which insurer may rely for defence; does not oust other defences like no accident, plaintiff negligent, contributory negligence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 96(2) and (3) Motor Vehicles Act, 1939; Order 1 Rule 10 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Insurer joined as party has right to take all defences permissible in law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: General law; apart from statute, insurer liable only to assured, not third party

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-s. (2) exhausts only defences based on conditions of policy; insurer can defend on other grounds in addition.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 96(2) Motor Vehicles Act; interpretation to avoid hardship

petitioner_arguments.text: Sub-s. (6) prohibits avoiding liability in manner other than stated in sub-s. (2), meaning procedure of joining as party, not limiting grounds.
Hardship if limited: third party and assured may collude, default, or compromise; insurer bound without hearing on merits, contrary to natural justice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Natural justice; Bombay cases recognizing hardship

petitioner_arguments.text: At common law, insurer/guarantor could be joined via third party procedure.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Common law; Halsbury; cases like United Provinces v. Atiqa Begum

respondent_arguments.text: s. 96(2) clearly specifies defences open to insurer; no ambiguity, cannot add defences.
Chapter VIII based on English Road Traffic Acts; historical development shows insurer limited to policy-related defences to protect third party.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Act ss. 94, 95, 96; English Road Traffic Acts 1930, 1934; Roughton Committee Report

respondent_arguments.text: s. 96 rolls up three English actions into one but gives no greater rights; at common law, insurer had no right to intervene on merits.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: English law; Shawcross on Motor Insurance; Halsbury

respondent_arguments.text: No hardship: insurer can recover from assured under ss. 96(3) proviso, (4); control proceedings clause; loss falls on insurer's business.
Insurer neither necessary nor proper party under O.1 R.10 CPC; complete adjudication possible without.
Bombay cases correct on limitation but wrong on hardship and defending in name of insured.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay cases; Windsor v. Chalcraft (dissent of Slesser LJ)

court_reasoning.text: Language of s.96(2) plain: insurer entitled to defend on any of the following grounds enumerated, and no others; specifying grounds means cannot add to them.
court_reasoning.key_observation: To allow other defences would add words to statute.

court_reasoning.text: s.96(6) confirms: insurer cannot avoid liability otherwise than in manner in sub-s.(2), i.e., by establishing enumerated defences.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Manner includes both procedure and specified grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Right to be party created by statute; content depends on statute; apart from statute, no right to be party.
Rejects argument sub-s.(2) only for policy conditions: clauses (a),(c) cover cancellation, non-disclosure not mere conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sub-s.(2) deals with defences other than policy conditions.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot add 'also' before 'grounds' to allow other defences; section clear, no ambiguity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules of interpretation do not permit.

court_reasoning.text: No hardship: insurer can defend in name of assured if reserved in policy; recover excess from assured under sub-ss.(3),(4).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Loss on insurer equitable as business risk.

holdings.text: An insurer added as defendant under s.96(2) is entitled to defend only on the grounds enumerated in that sub-section and no others.

precedents_cited.relevance: Proceeded on basis insurer no right to defend except on s.96(2) grounds

precedents_cited.case_name: Royal Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Abdul Mahomed
precedents_cited.relevance: Proceeded on basis insurer no right to defend except on s.96(2) grounds

precedents_cited.relevance: Proceeded on basis insurer no right to defend except on s.96(2) grounds

statutes_cited.relevance: Compulsory third party insurance; insurer's liability to satisfy judgment; right to be party and limited defences; recovery from assured

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by the insurers, upholding the Punjab High Court view that insurers added under s.96(2) can defend only on the enumerated grounds and no others.

key_quotes.text: It is that an insurer to whom the requisite notice of the action has been given shall be entitled to be made a party thereto and to defend the action on any of the following grounds, namely...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Plain language limiting defences to enumerated grounds

key_quotes.text: No insurer to whom the notice referred to in sub-section (2) has been given shall be entitled to avoid his liability... otherwise than in the manner provided for in sub-section (2).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: s.96(6) confirms limitation via sub-s.(2) manner and grounds

key_quotes.text: When the grounds of defence have been specified, they cannot be added to. To do that would be adding words to the statute.
key_quotes.speaker: court
